aircraft.name: Lightning

source.name: National Museum of the USAF P-38 Lightning Fact Sheet

aircraft.description: The P-38 Lightning was one of the most effective and versatile fighter aircraft of World War II. Its distinctive twin-boom design, twin-engine power, and heavy armament made it a formidable interceptor and fighter-bomber. The Lightning proved particularly effective in the Pacific Theater, where its long range and twin-engine reliability were crucial advantages.

aircraft.name: Neptune
aircraft.type: Maritime Patrol and Anti-Submarine Warfare Aircraft

source.name: US Navy Historical Records

aircraft.description: The P-2 Neptune was a maritime patrol and anti-submarine warfare aircraft developed for the United States Navy. It was a successful design that served from 1947 to 1984, playing a crucial role in maritime operations during the Cold War.

differences.notes: Final production variant with J34-WE-36 jet engines and extended MAD boom

aircraft.name: Dragon Lady

source.name: USAF U-2S Dragon Lady Fact Sheet

aircraft.description: The U-2S Dragon Lady provides high-altitude, all-weather surveillance and reconnaissance in direct support of U.S. and allied forces. It delivers critical imagery and signals intelligence to decision makers throughout all phases of conflict, including peacetime indications and warnings, low-intensity conflict, and large-scale hostilities.

aircraft.name: Starfighter

source.name: National Museum of the USAF F-104 Fact Sheet

aircraft.description: The F-104 Starfighter was a single-engine, supersonic interceptor aircraft that set numerous world records for speed and altitude. Known as the 'Missile with a Man in It' due to its distinctive design and high performance capabilities.

differences.notes: Initial production interceptor variant for USAF
Multi-role fighter-bomber variant for NATO allies

aircraft.name: Orion
aircraft.type: Maritime Patrol and Anti-Submarine Warfare Aircraft

differences.notes: Enhanced anti-submarine warfare capabilities, updated avionics

source.name: US Navy P-3 Orion Fact Sheet

aircraft.description: The P-3 Orion is a long-range, anti-submarine warfare patrol aircraft. It has been the U.S. Navy's frontline, land-based maritime patrol aircraft since 1962.

aircraft.name: Blackbird

engines.type: Pratt & Whitney J58-P4 continuous-bleed afterburning turbojet

source.name: National Museum of the USAF SR-71 Fact Sheet

aircraft.description: The SR-71 Blackbird was the world's fastest and highest-flying operational aircraft. Developed in secrecy by Lockheed's Skunk Works, it was designed to outrace any missile fired at it. The Blackbird's titanium construction and special design allowed it to cope with the extreme temperatures generated by sustained Mach 3+ flight.

aircraft.name: Super Galaxy

source.name: USAF C-5M Super Galaxy Fact Sheet

aircraft.description: The C-5M Super Galaxy is one of the largest military aircraft in the world and the largest airlifter in the U.S. Air Force inventory. Its primary mission is to transport cargo and personnel for the Department of Defense. The aircraft can carry fully equipped combat-ready military units to any point in the world on short notice and provide field support required to help sustain the fighting force.

aircraft.name: TriStar

source.name: NASA L-1011 TriStar Technical Specifications

aircraft.description: The L-1011 TriStar was Lockheed's entry into the wide-body commercial airliner market. Known for its advanced technology, including its innovative autopilot system capable of Category IIIc automated landings, the TriStar was one of the first wide-body aircraft to receive FAA certification for automated landings in zero-visibility conditions. The aircraft's distinctive three-engine configuration, with one engine mounted in the tail, and excellent reliability earned it a reputation for technical excellence, though it faced stiff competition from the McDonnell Douglas DC-10.

aircraft.name: Nighthawk

source.name: National Museum of the USAF F-117 Fact Sheet

aircraft.description: The F-117 Nighthawk was the world's first operational stealth aircraft, designed to penetrate dense threat environments and attack high-value targets with precision guided weapons.

aircraft.name: Super Hercules

source.name: USAF C-130J Super Hercules Fact Sheet

aircraft.description: The C-130J-30 Super Hercules is an extended-length version of the tactical airlifter that has served as the backbone of military transport operations worldwide. This modernized variant features advanced digital avionics, more powerful engines, and improved cargo handling capabilities, making it one of the most versatile and reliable transport aircraft in service.

aircraft.name: Raptor

source.name: USAF F-22 Raptor Fact Sheet

aircraft.description: The F-22A Raptor represents the pinnacle of air superiority fighter design, combining stealth technology, supermaneuverability, and advanced avionics. It was the world's first operational fifth-generation fighter, capable of both air-to-air and air-to-ground missions with unprecedented effectiveness.

aircraft.name: Lightning II
aircraft.description: The F-35 Lightning II is a 5th-generation multi-role stealth fighter developed as part of the Joint Strike Fighter program. It comes in three variants: F-35A (conventional takeoff), F-35B (short takeoff/vertical landing), and F-35C (carrier variant).

source.name: USAF F-35 Lightning II Fact Sheet

aircraft.description: The F-35 Lightning II is a 5th-generation multi-role stealth fighter developed as part of the Joint Strike Fighter program. It comes in three variants: F-35A (conventional takeoff), F-35B (short takeoff/vertical landing), and F-35C (carrier variant).

aircraft.name: Flying Fortress

source.name: National Museum of the USAF B-17G Flying Fortress Fact Sheet

aircraft.description: The B-17G Flying Fortress was one of the most famous bombers of World War II. Known for its durability and defensive firepower, it could sustain heavy damage and still return home. The G variant was the most numerous and technologically advanced model, featuring enhanced defensive armament and improved flight systems.

aircraft.name: Superfortress
aircraft.description: The B-29 Superfortress was a four-engine heavy bomber that served as the primary American strategic bomber in the Pacific Theater during World War II. It was the most advanced bomber of its time, featuring a pressurized cabin, remote-controlled gun turrets, and advanced radar systems.

source.name: National Museum of the USAF B-29 Superfortress Fact Sheet

aircraft.name: Stratofortress

source.name: USAF B-52 Fact Sheet

aircraft.description: The B-52H Stratofortress is one of the most enduring aircraft designs in military history. First introduced in the 1950s, it remains a cornerstone of America's strategic forces. Its massive payload capacity, long range, and continuous upgrades have kept it relevant for over 60 years, with plans to continue service into the 2050s.

aircraft.name: Chinook
aircraft.description: The CH-47F Chinook is a twin-engine, tandem rotor heavy-lift helicopter. It is among the heaviest lifting Western helicopters, primarily used for troop movement, artillery placement, and battlefield resupply. Its tandem rotor configuration eliminates the need for an anti-torque vertical rotor, allowing all engine power to be used for lift and thrust.

aircraft.name: Thunderbolt II

source.name: USAF A-10 Thunderbolt II Fact Sheet

aircraft.description: The A-10C Thunderbolt II, affectionately known as the 'Warthog', was designed specifically for close air support of ground forces. Built around its powerful 30mm GAU-8 Avenger cannon, the A-10's durability, simple design, and ability to operate from austere airfields have made it an invaluable asset in ground attack missions.

aircraft.name: Hornet

source.name: US Navy F/A-18 Hornet Fact File

aircraft.description: The F/A-18 Hornet is a twin-engine, supersonic combat jet designed for both air-to-air and air-to-ground missions. The aircraft's versatility and reliability have made it a mainstay of carrier aviation and the aircraft of choice for several military forces worldwide.

aircraft.name: Strike Eagle

source.name: USAF F-15E Strike Eagle Fact Sheet

aircraft.description: The F-15E Strike Eagle is a dual-role fighter designed for air-to-air and air-to-ground missions. An evolution of the F-15 Eagle air superiority fighter, the Strike Eagle adds sophisticated navigation and radar systems for ground attack missions while maintaining the air combat capabilities that made the original F-15 undefeated in aerial combat.

aircraft.name: Super Hornet

source.name: US Navy F/A-18E/F Super Hornet Fact File

aircraft.description: The F/A-18E/F Super Hornet is a significantly larger and more advanced evolution of the original Hornet design. It features improved range, greater payload capacity, enhanced survivability, and more advanced avionics than its predecessor while maintaining the versatility and reliability that made the original Hornet successful.

aircraft.name: NGAD

source.name: USAF Official Announcement

aircraft.description: The F-47 is the U.S. Air Force's sixth-generation fighter aircraft developed under the Next Generation Air Dominance (NGAD) program. Designed to be significantly more advanced than fifth-generation fighters, it features enhanced stealth capabilities, increased range, and is intended to operate with accompanying autonomous collaborative combat aircraft (CCA). The aircraft will serve as the successor to the F-22 Raptor.

aircraft.name: Freedom Fighter/Tiger II
aircraft.description: The F-5 is a supersonic light fighter aircraft designed as a cost-effective combat aircraft. The F-5E Tiger II variant introduced improved radar, avionics, and increased fuel capacity. Known for its agility, low operating costs, and reliability, it has been widely exported and continues to serve in multiple air forces worldwide.

variants.name: Tiger II
variants.description: Improved single-seat version with better avionics and increased fuel capacity

aircraft.source: USAF Fact Sheet, Jane's All The World's Aircraft

aircraft.name: Intruder
aircraft.description: The Grumman A-6 Intruder was a twin-engine, mid-wing all-weather attack aircraft developed for the U.S. Navy and Marine Corps. It was designed to operate from aircraft carriers and land bases for long-range interdiction missions. The A-6 featured advanced navigation and attack systems including DIANE (Digital Integrated Attack/Navigation Equipment) and later TRAM (Target Recognition Attack Multisensor), allowing precision strikes in any weather conditions, day or night.
variants: A-6B: Modified for Iron Hand SAM suppression missions
A-6C: Modified with TRIM pod for night attack
A-6E: Improved version with updated avionics and new wing

aircraft.name: Advanced Hawkeye
aircraft.description: The E-2D Advanced Hawkeye is an all-weather, carrier-capable tactical airborne early warning (AEW) aircraft. It features the AN/APY-9 radar system with both mechanical and electronic scanning capabilities, advanced mission computer, integrated satellite communications, flight management system, and aerial refueling capability. The aircraft is operated by a crew of five and provides command and control capabilities for carrier battle groups.

variants.description: Upgraded E-2A with improved computer systems and enlarged outer fins
Major upgrade with new electronics, APS-145 radar and improved mission systems
Latest variant with APY-9 radar, new mission computer, glass cockpit, and aerial refueling capability

aircraft.name: Greyhound
aircraft.description: The C-2A Greyhound is a twin-engine, high-wing cargo aircraft designed to carry supplies, mail, and passengers to and from aircraft carriers of the United States Navy. Its primary mission is carrier onboard delivery (COD). The aircraft can deliver up to 10,000 pounds of cargo or up to 26 passengers, and is equipped for medical evacuation missions. Features include folding wings for carrier operations, a rear loading ramp, and powered winch for cargo handling.

variants.description: Reprocured C-2A with improved systems based on the E-2C variant, 39 built

aircraft.name: Tomcat

variants.description: Initial production variant with TF30 engines
Final variant with improved avionics and F110-GE-400 engines

aircraft.description: The F-14 Tomcat was a supersonic, twin-engine, two-seat, variable-sweep wing fighter aircraft. Developed for the United States Navy's Naval Fighter Experimental (VFX) program after the collapse of the F-111B project, the F-14 was the first of the American teen-series fighters which were designed incorporating air combat experience against MiG aircraft during the Vietnam War.
aircraft.source: US Navy Fact File, Naval Air Systems Command

aircraft.name: Prowler
aircraft.description: The EA-6B Prowler was a long-range, all-weather electronic warfare aircraft developed from the A-6 Intruder platform. It was designed to jam enemy radar systems and gather electronic intelligence, serving as the U.S. military's primary electronic warfare platform until its retirement.
variants: EA-6B ICAP I - Initial electronic warfare capability
EA-6B ICAP II - Improved electronic warfare systems
EA-6B ICAP III - Final upgrade with enhanced electronic attack capabilities
aircraft.source: U.S. Navy Fact File, Naval Air Systems Command

aircraft.name: Black Widow II
aircraft.description: The YF-23 was Northrop's entry for the Advanced Tactical Fighter competition, competing against the Lockheed YF-22. While demonstrating exceptional stealth characteristics and supercruise capability, it ultimately lost to the YF-22. Only two prototypes were built: PAV-1 (painted black) and PAV-2 (painted gray).
aircraft.source: USAF Museum, Northrop Grumman historical records

aircraft.name: Fire Scout
aircraft.description: The MQ-8 Fire Scout is an unmanned autonomous helicopter developed for the United States Armed Forces. It provides reconnaissance, situational awareness, aerial fire support and precision targeting support. The latest MQ-8C variant is based on the Bell 407 airframe and offers increased range, altitude and payload capacity.

variants.description: Initial operational variant based on the Schweizer 333 airframe
Improved variant based on the Bell 407 airframe with increased payload and endurance

sources: Northrop Grumman MQ-8C Fire Scout factsheet
U.S. Navy MQ-8 Fire Scout fact file

aircraft.name: UCAS-D
aircraft.description: The X-47B was an unmanned combat air system demonstrator (UCAS-D) designed to demonstrate autonomous carrier operations. It successfully conducted the first autonomous carrier-based launch and recovery operations, and demonstrated autonomous aerial refueling capabilities.

source.name: U.S. Navy X-47B UCAS Fact Sheet

aircraft.name: Spirit

source.name: USAF B-2 Spirit Fact Sheet

aircraft.description: The B-2 Spirit is a multi-role stealth bomber capable of delivering both conventional and nuclear munitions. Its low-observable, or 'stealth,' characteristics give it the ability to penetrate sophisticated defensive networks. The aircraft's unique flying wing design and advanced composite materials make it virtually invisible to radar systems.

aircraft.name: Global Hawk

source.name: USAF RQ-4 Global Hawk Fact Sheet

aircraft.description: The RQ-4 Global Hawk is a high-altitude, long-endurance unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) developed by Northrop Grumman for the United States Air Force. It is designed for intelligence, surveillance, and reconnaissance (ISR) missions, and can operate from both land and sea platforms.

aircraft.name: Raider
aircraft.description: The B-21 Raider is a strategic stealth bomber developed as part of the Long Range Strike Bomber (LRS-B) program. It is the world's first sixth-generation aircraft and is designed to be a long-range, highly survivable bomber capable of penetrating advanced air defenses to deliver both conventional and nuclear weapons. The aircraft features advanced stealth technology, digital engineering, and an open systems architecture for rapid upgrades.

notes: All specifications are from official U.S. Air Force and National Museum fact sheets
Some performance data may be limited due to operational security
Database will be expanded as more verified information becomes available
